_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: Utilize Minnesota Department of Agriculture forms for maintenance inspections on all equipment
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: NOTE:  No equipment on site as of date of this filing.  WFS reviewed with installer the details of NEW equipment to be installed at site
_prev_prog_2.Description: The facility complies with the various rules and regulations governing the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.  Inspection, maintenance and employee training are important components of our accident prevention program

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Watonwan Farm Service Company

233 West Ciro Street

PO Box 68

Truman, MN 56088

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY PROPOSED



1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:



The Coop board, management and employees at Watonwan Farm Service, Mankato, MN location, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.



2. Facility Information and Regulated Substances Handled: 



The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and handled for direct application. Anhydrous ammonia is used for crop production nutrients. The facility will have 1-45,000 gallon storage tank; and additional available capacity of approximately 20,000 gallons in nurse tanks when the nurse tanks are on site during the spring planting and fall harvest seasons. The maximum quantity handled would be a tank truck holding 40,000-45,000 pounds.



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



The facility has implemented Minnesota Dept. of Agriculture rules, the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and 40 CFR part 68 as they apply to this facility. The facility is required to conduct a semi-annual inspection of all bulk and nurse tank equipment, including load and unload equipment, and perform any needed maintenance to the equipment found during the inspections. Visual checks are to be conducted daily at the facility.



4. The Five-year Accident History:



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have:

a) Caused any death, inj

uries, or significant property damage at the facility; or

b) Resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or

environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Response Program:



The facility:

a)Has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and 40 CFR 68.95. The plan includes a specific section on NH3 Releases and what to do in the event of a release. The annual emergency action plan training was held in July 2014 and August 2014. Additional review of emergency response training fo anhydrous ammonia was part of the annual anhydrous ammonia training that was held in September 2014.

b) Will provide state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

c) Coordinated with local emergency responders.

d) Has Safety Data Sheets for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan information.

e) A Minnesota AWAIR (A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community and environment in which we operate.





6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Currently, there is no storage tanks and no anhydrous ammonia on site.  This RMP will be updated as required once the facility becomes operational.
